Simply the best thrift store I've ever been to. Well worth the 3 1/2 hour drive from my hometown.

First, and foremost, EVERYTHING IS 1/2 off all of the time!

Secondly, bring cash. They DO NOT accept credit cards.

The store is full of wonderful pieces of clothing, all arranged by color and type (not by size, which is unfortunate). I found a wide selection of everything from casual pieces to high-end business attire to super-trendy teen clothing... what surprised me most about this store was the QUALITY of the clothing. Almost all of the pieces were flawless, a few were worn or faded in some way and the price reflected that. Brand names were bountiful; Banana Republic, Ralph Lauren, Chico's, Jones New York, Ann Taylor, American Eagle, H&M. There were also some wonderful vintage pieces from the 80s, bright colors and crazy shoulder pads that would have made a more adventurous fashionista very happy indeed!

The clothing smells wonderful, not musty or dirty as in some thrift stores, and there was even a large selection of plus-sized clothing carefully culled out in a special section.

I went to Red White & Blue to find some business attire for my new job, and came home with two gorgeous, flawless statement blazers from Ann Taylor Loft and Banana Republic... for a total of $7!

Come to this thrift store; it'll make all other shopping obsolete!
target:
I have visited many thrift stores, but this one tops them all. Despite having to drive 3 1/2 hours from my hometown, I can say it's definitely worth it.

One of the best things about this store is that everything is always half-off, which is a huge plus in my book. However, be sure to bring cash as they don't accept credit cards.

The clothing is arranged by color and type, which is great, but unfortunately not by size. Nonetheless, I found a variety of clothing options ranging from casual wear to high-end business attire to trendy teen fashion. What sets this thrift store apart is the quality of the clothing. Nearly all the pieces I saw were flawless, while some showed minor signs of wear and tear, and were priced accordingly. I was pleasantly surprised to find numerous brand names such as Banana Republic, Ralph Lauren, Chico's, Jones New York, Ann Taylor, American Eagle, and H&M. For those who enjoy vintage finds, they have an excellent selection of 80s pieces, which are colorful and feature crazy shoulder pads. 

The clothing doesn't have a musty or dirty smell that some other thrift stores exude. They even had a whole section for plus-sized clothing. 

I visited Red White & Blue thrift store to purchase some business attire for my new job and was thrilled to find two gorgeous blazers from Ann Taylor Loft and Banana Republic for a total of just $7.

If you're looking for a thrift store that has everything, this is the one to visit. It will spoil you for any other shopping experiences.

source: I cannot imagine a more miserable place to shop than this jam-packed monstrosity.  This is a store that makes me thankful for Goodwill and The Salvation Army resale stores.  The customers and the staff are miserable at Red White and Blue.  The clothes are priced far higher than other such shops.  Merchandise is not refundable or exchangeable, and there are no fitting rooms!  One purchases clothes at their own risk!  What person would buy a suit under these conditions, hoping the pants will fit?  Unlike other stores, there is no senior discount and no credit cards accepted, a rare cash only business.  To the reviewer who boasts that everything is 50% off every day, how is that a sale?  It is bogus pricing.  Red White and Blue, uggh!
target: This store is a nightmare to shop in. I would much rather go to Goodwill or The Salvation Army. The atmosphere at Red White and Blue is gloomy, and both the customers and staff seem unhappy. Their clothes are overpriced compared to other similar stores, and there are no fitting rooms. The store doesn't offer refunds or exchanges, so purchasing clothing there is risky. They don't accept credit cards and there aren't any senior discounts available. While they claim to offer 50% off every day, it's not really a sale, but just false advertising. In short, I'd say Red White and Blue is a terrible store.

source: Ever shopped at a Thrift Shop that sells high end labels, some brand new and gently used items like backpacks for $5? This is a great place to discover unique things. They also have daily deals such as 1/2 off of certain color tags. Have to dig through other things though to find something interesting which is part of the adventure!
target: Have you explored a thrift store that offers top-tier brands, some items in mint condition, and backpacks under $5? It's an ideal spot to stumble upon exclusive finds. They also offer daily discounts on specific color tags. Be prepared to scour through other items to uncover something fascinating, that's part of the thrill!

source: Love the store. Great stuff, High price. Buyer BEWARE of the RUDE cashier SYLVIA, extremely unpleasant, unwilling to help and always with NEGATIVE attitude. She needs customer service training....Someone please tell her to stop complaining about other customers or employees....Cashier that does window display is always kind, friendly and helpful.
target: I really like the store and they have amazing products, but the prices are quite steep. However, I want to caution you about the cashier named SYLVIA who is consistently unhelpful, rude, and negative towards customers. I think she could definitely use some customer service training. In addition, it would be great if someone can tell her to stop complaining about other customers and employees. On a more positive note, the cashier who manages the window display is always polite, helpful, and friendly.

source:
I love a deal, and this has been my favorite thrift store since I was a kid.  

First, there is some sort of half-off deal every day.

Second, the used book selection is pretty decent.  Yeah, there are a ton of self-help and Patterson mass markets that you have wade through, but T.C. Boyle for two bucks?  Yes, please.

Third, the home goods.  I've gotten huge solid wood picture frames for only a couple dollars.  The art prints inside were hideous...but I threw those away, re-stained the frames to my liking, cut new mats, and inserting art quoted as $360 each to frame at a big chain fabric store for under $30.  Boom.

Finally, there is a decent selection of lamp to re-wire, always lot of furniture, some diamond in the rough clothes on occasion, and lots of other wacky stuff that's just fun to sift through.

CASH ONLY and the cashiers are pretty rude/lazy, but that never bothers me.

BONUS:  They pick up your donations for free from your porch.  http://www.pickupplease.org/  Super easy.
target: This thrift store has been my favorite since childhood because I'm always on the hunt for a bargain. The daily half-off deals are definitely a highlight for me. The used book section is a treasure trove too - while there are plenty of self-help books, I've managed to snag some T.C. Boyle novels for only two bucks. For home goods, I've found some solid wood frames that needed a bit of love, which I re-stained and inserted my own artwork to create beautiful statement pieces. The store also has a good selection of furniture and lamps to re-wire, as well as the occasional diamond in the rough clothing item. Just be prepared to pay with cash and deal with some not-so-friendly cashiers. Plus, if you're looking to donate, they offer free porch pick-up services.
